So, here’s the deal: I gave Zametov a bit of a beating back then—just between us, okay? Don’t spill the beans; he’s a sensitive topic. It happened at Luise Ivanovna’s place. But today? Everything’s clear now. That Ilya Petrovitch guy is the real culprit! He totally took advantage of you fainting at the police station, but now he feels bad about it. I can tell. 

Raskolnikov was all ears. Razumihin had enough drinks to spill the tea. 

“I fainted because it was super stuffy and the paint smell was awful,” Raskolnikov said. 

“No need to explain! It wasn’t just the paint. You’ve been running a fever for a month. Zossimov backs me up on that! But man, that kid is crushed now. He thinks he’s not worth your little finger—yours, not mine. He has a heart sometimes. But that lesson you gave him at the Palais de Cristal? Priceless! You scared him so much he almost freaked out! You nearly made him believe that awful nonsense again, then you just stuck out your tongue at him: ‘So, what do you think now?’ Perfect! He’s totally wrecked! It was genius, honestly! Wish I could’ve been there! He was really hoping to see you. Porfiry wants to meet you too…”

“Ah! … but why did they think I was mad?” 

“Oh, not mad. I might have said too much, brother… What surprised him was that only that topic seemed to…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov learns about the impact of his actions on others while discussing a recent incident with Razumihin.
